articles.headline: Supreme Court Rejects F.C.C. Fines for Indecency
articles.snippet: The justices declined to address whether the government still had the authority to regulate indecency on broadcast television, but excused two broadcasters from fines.
articles.abstract: The justices declined to address whether the government still had the authority to regulate indecency on broadcast television, but excused two broadcasters from fines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON —   The Supreme Court on Thursday declined to address whether the government still has the authority to regulate indecency on broadcast television, but it ruled in favor of two broadcasters who had faced potential fines for programs featuring cursing and nudity on narrow grounds.

articles.headline: Natural Gas for Vehicles Could Use U.S. Support
articles.snippet: The arguments for a federal program to promote natural gas vehicles are compelling. So where’s the political support?
articles.abstract: The arguments for a federal program to promote natural gas vehicles are compelling. So where’s the political support?
articles.lead_paragraph: The fuel is cheap and plentiful. But there is little infrastructure to deliver it to users, and so there is little demand for equipment to use it.

articles.headline: Moody’s Cuts Credit Ratings of 15 Big Banks
articles.snippet: After putting banks on watch four months ago, Moody’s Investors Service on Thursday cut the credit ratings of 15 large financial firms, in a move that could do lasting damage to their bottom lines and weigh on the markets.
articles.abstract: After putting banks on watch four months ago, Moody’s Investors Service on Thursday cut the credit ratings of 15 large financial firms, in a move that could do lasting damage to their bottom lines and weigh on the markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: 10:33 p.m. | Updated Already grappling with weak profits and global economic turmoil, 15 major banks were hit with credit downgrades on Thursday that could do more damage to their bottom lines and further unsettle equity markets.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: As Growth Ebbs, Brazil Powers Up Its Bulldozers
articles.snippet: President Dilma Rousseff is accelerating stimulus projects aimed at blunting the slowdown, a demonstration of the extraordinary sway the government has over the economy.
articles.abstract: President Dilma Rousseff is accelerating stimulus projects aimed at blunting the slowdown, a demonstration of the extraordinary sway the government has over the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: IPOJUCA, Brazil — More than 40,000 laborers swarm the port complex here in northeast Brazil, building a refinery for the state oil company. Five thousand others toil at a shipyard, another government-led project. Real estate prices are soaring and unemployment is falling in this region along the Atlantic coast, once known for its festering poverty.

articles.headline: Billions of Dollars Are in Play Over Health Care Law
articles.snippet: It is unclear what would happen to the money for a host of programs if the Affordable Care Act is overturned.
articles.abstract: It is unclear what would happen to the money for a host of programs if the Affordable Care Act is overturned.
articles.lead_paragraph: PEEKSKILL, N.Y. — In this small city about an hour from Manhattan, pregnant teenagers, laid-off professionals and day laborers without insurance receive care at a community health center that has been part of the social fabric here for nearly four decades.

articles.headline: Ratings Downgrade Cuts Deeply at Morgan Stanley
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley, the former risk-taking brokerage that is now a bank, faces financial and psychological challenges.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley, the former risk-taking brokerage that is now a bank, faces financial and psychological challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Moody’s Investors Service prepared to cut the ratings of some of the world’s biggest financial firms on Thursday, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, was in St. Petersburg, Russia. He spoke to a group of business and economic leaders about how banks would have rethink their roles in an environment characterized by more regulation and falling profits.

articles.headline: As Facebook Seeks Answers, S.E.C. Investigates Exchanges
articles.snippet: Investor confidence in the markets has waned after problems on the day Facebook shares began trading.
articles.abstract: Investor confidence in the markets has waned after problems on the day Facebook shares began trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nasdaq has blamed Facebook’s botched debut last month on flawed computers and “technical errors.”
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Evelyn M. Rusli and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Union, on Heels of Wisconsin Recall Vote, Selects a New President
articles.snippet: At their convention, the Afscme delegates elevated the union’s secretary-treasurer, Lee Saunders.
articles.abstract: At their convention, the Afscme delegates elevated the union’s secretary-treasurer, Lee Saunders.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Nearly 3,000 delegates from the nation’s largest union of state and local government employees gathered here this week. Judging from the talk on the convention floor, one would hardly know that they had experienced a huge defeat this month in their effort to recall Wisconsin’s governor, or that they faced lawmakers and voters across the country who have grown increasingly unsympathetic to public sector workers.

articles.headline: NBC News Faces Shift in Television Dominance
articles.snippet: As ratings across its weekday morning, nightly and Sunday morning franchises decline, the network appears vulnerable.
articles.abstract: As ratings across its weekday morning, nightly and Sunday morning franchises decline, the network appears vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC News has long been a dominant presence on network television, regularly winning the ratings competition against its evening news and Sunday morning political show competitors, and reveling in the “Today” show’s 16-year winning streak in morning television, a record not broken until April.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Romney Exhibits a Change in Tone on Immigration
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney struck a more conciliatory tone toward illegal immigrants than he has in the past, but backed only limited steps to address the concerns of many Hispanic voters.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney struck a more conciliatory tone toward illegal immigrants than he has in the past, but backed only limited steps to address the concerns of many Hispanic voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Mitt Romney struck a more conciliatory tone toward illegal immigrants on Thursday than he took during the Republican primary season, but he backed only limited steps to address the concerns of many Hispanic voters as he confronted one of the trickiest issues in his efforts to build a broad general election coalition.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: Elite Women Put a New Spin on an Old Debate
articles.snippet: A magazine article by a former Obama administration official has blown up into an instant debate about a new conundrum of female success.
articles.abstract: A magazine article by a former Obama administration official has blown up into an instant debate about a new conundrum of female success.
articles.lead_paragraph: If a woman has a sterling résumé, a supportive husband who speaks fluent car pool and a nurturing boss who just happens to be one of the most powerful women in the world herself, who or what is to blame if Ms. Supposed-to-Have-It-All still cannot balance work and family?
